content.raw: I think we need an Ignition architecture design document. The document referenced above is relevant to Gazebo. I'll put that on my todo list. Edit: I added an anasa task for blueprint.
content.html: I think we need an Ignition architecture design document. The document referenced above is relevant to Gazebo. I'll put that on my todo list. Edit: I added an anasa task for blueprint.

content.raw: The problem is related to dependencies. I wanted to store the plugins here, but the plugins can cause circular dependencies. I could move everything back to `ign-launch`, and not touch tools.
content.html: The problem is related to dependencies. I wanted to store the plugins here, but the plugins can cause circular dependencies. I could move everything back to ign-launch, and not touch tools.

content.raw: Just a thought: Is there any reason to not store the `ign-plugins` plugins in `ign-launch`? The package name `ign-plugins` will get easily and frequently confused with `ign-plugin`, but if they could be kept in `ign-launch` then that could avoid the confusion.
content.html: Just a thought: Is there any reason to not store the ign-plugins plugins in ign-launch? The package name ign-plugins will get easily and frequently confused with ign-plugin, but if they could be kept in ign-launch then that could avoid the confusion.

content.raw:
After looking at the plugins in [ign-plugins](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-plugins/pull-requests), I think the type of plugin supported by the functionality add in this PR is:

* analogous to ‘system plugins’ in gazebo classic

* standalone \(no dependency on ign-gazebo\)

Let me know if I misunderstood anything. It may help to update the Plugins section in [architecture design](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/src/default/doc/architecture_design.md) document to clarify this. Now I see that we have 2 types of plugins: 1\) ign-gazebo systems \(e.g. diff drive\), and 2\) these launch plugins.
content.html:
After looking at the plugins in ign-plugins, I think the type of plugin supported by the functionality add in this PR is:

  • analogous to ‘system plugins’ in gazebo classic

  • standalone (no dependency on ign-gazebo)

Let me know if I misunderstood anything. It may help to update the Plugins section in architecture design document to clarify this. Now I see that we have 2 types of plugins: 1) ign-gazebo systems (e.g. diff drive), and 2) these launch plugins.

update.description:
This is ready, test have been added.

This will allow ign-gazebo to be used as a library and allow plugins to be specified via ServerConfig.

# Testing

1. Install all the plugins from the [ign-plugins](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-plugins) repo.
2. Install the last of the [ign-tools prs](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-tools/pull-requests/9).
3. Install this PR.
4. Run `ign launch -f gazebo_plugins.ign`.
update.title: [A-7] Allow programmatic loading of plugins

content.raw:
The changes here look ok to me, my only 2 concerns are:

* A single config is shared among all `SimulationRunner`s, and consequently among all worlds - not sure if we want more flexibility than that.
* This is currently not using scoped names, so it will be hard to support plugins that are nested more deeply, such as visual plugins and sensor plugins.

I haven't looked into the other repositories.
content.html:
The changes here look ok to me, my only 2 concerns are:

  • A single config is shared among all SimulationRunners, and consequently among all worlds - not sure if we want more flexibility than that.
  • This is currently not using scoped names, so it will be hard to support plugins that are nested more deeply, such as visual plugins and sensor plugins.

I haven't looked into the other repositories.

content.raw: If there are multiple `<world>`s in the SDF file, this will be attached to `<model name="box">` in each of them. Is this the intention? If scoped names are used, then it would be possible to have a more targetted attachment with `::world::shapes::model::box` for example.
content.html: If there are multiple <world>s in the SDF file, this will be attached to <model name="box"> in each of them. Is this the intention? If scoped names are used, then it would be possible to have a more targetted attachment with ::world::shapes::model::box for example.

content.raw: Do we want to remove plugins from the list after they're loaded?
content.html: Do we want to remove plugins from the list after they're loaded?

components::Name is not scoped, so this wouldn't be able to tell apart 2 visuals called visual from different links.

How about using the full scoped name of an entity? Using the Utils.hh header you could do something like this:

auto name = scopedName(_entity, this->entityCompMgr, "::");
if (name != plugin.EntityScopedName())
  continue;

content.raw: Actually this whole function could use a few more warnings and errors
content.html: Actually this whole function could use a few more warnings and errors

content.raw: Do we want to print a warning when these are missing?
content.html: Do we want to print a warning when these are missing?

content.raw: This is ok if we're sure that it is never going to change (which is usually a dangerous assumption). An alternative would be to set all the fields after construction.
content.html: This is ok if we're sure that it is never going to change (which is usually a dangerous assumption). An alternative would be to set all the fields after construction.

content.raw: I was just thinking of the [Rule of five](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rule_of_three_(C%2B%2B_programming)#Rule_of_Five)
content.html: I was just thinking of the Rule of five

content.raw: Same as above, I don't think it's needed.
content.html: Same as above, I don't think it's needed.

content.raw: I didn't need it, so I didn't add it. Do you see a place where it is needed?
content.html: I didn't need it, so I didn't add it. Do you see a place where it is needed?

content.raw: Same here, consider adding move operator and constructor.
content.html: Same here, consider adding move operator and constructor.

content.raw: Consider also adding move constructor and operator
content.html: Consider also adding move constructor and operator

content.raw: We shouldn't need to change old files, right?
content.html: We shouldn't need to change old files, right?
